clauses.title: DOCUMENT HEADER: EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT TEMPLATE (UK)
clauses.content:
EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT TEMPLATE (UK)

This Contract of Employment is made between [COMPANY NAME], a company incorporated in England and Wales ("Company"), and [EMPLOYEE NAME] ("Employee").

clauses.title: POSITION AND DUTIES
clauses.content:
1. POSITION AND DUTIES
The Employee shall be employed as [POSITION TITLE] and shall perform such duties as are reasonably required, including but not limited to:
- [DUTY 1]
- [DUTY 2]
- [DUTY 3]

clauses.title: SALARY AND BENEFITS
clauses.content:
2. SALARY AND BENEFITS
The Company shall pay the Employee a gross annual salary of £[AMOUNT], payable monthly in arrears by BACS transfer. The Employee shall be entitled to participate in the Company's pension scheme and other benefits as detailed in the Employee Handbook.

clauses.title: WORKING TIME
clauses.content:
3. WORKING TIME
Normal working hours are [HOURS] per week, Monday to Friday. The Employee may be required to work reasonable additional hours as necessary for the proper performance of duties.

clauses.title: HOLIDAY ENTITLEMENT
clauses.content:
4. HOLIDAY ENTITLEMENT
The Employee is entitled to [NUMBER] days' paid annual leave plus bank holidays, pro-rated for part-time employees.

clauses.title: CONFIDENTIALITY
clauses.content:
5. CONFIDENTIALITY
The Employee acknowledges that they will have access to confidential information and agrees to maintain strict confidentiality during and after employment in accordance with the Data Protection Act 2018 and UK GDPR.

clauses.title: RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS
clauses.content:
6. RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS
For a period of [TIME PERIOD] months after termination, the Employee agrees not to:
- Compete with the Company within [GEOGRAPHIC AREA]
- Solicit Company clients or customers
- Solicit Company employees

clauses.title: TERMINATION
clauses.content:
7. TERMINATION
Either party may terminate this contract by giving [NOTICE PERIOD] written notice. The Company may terminate without notice for gross misconduct, including but not limited to:
- Serious breach of contract
- Criminal conviction affecting employment
- Gross negligence or misconduct

clauses.title: GOVERNING LAW
clauses.content:
8. GOVERNING LAW
This contract shall be governed by English law and subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the English courts.

IN WITNESS WHEREOF the parties have executed this Contract on the date first written below.

SIGNED: _____________________    SIGNED: _____________________
[COMPANY NAME]                   [EMPLOYEE NAME]
Date: _______________           Date: _______________

clauses.title: DOCUMENT HEADER: SERVICE AGREEMENT TEMPLATE (UK)
clauses.content:
SERVICE AGREEMENT TEMPLATE (UK)

This Service Agreement is made between [CLIENT NAME] ("Client") and [SERVICE PROVIDER NAME] ("Provider").

clauses.title: SERVICES
clauses.content:
1. SERVICES
The Provider agrees to provide the following services:
- [SERVICE 1]
- [SERVICE 2]
- [SERVICE 3]

clauses.title: PAYMENT TERMS
clauses.content:
2. PAYMENT TERMS
The Client agrees to pay the Provider according to the following schedule:
- Total contract value: £[AMOUNT] (inclusive/exclusive of VAT)
- Payment schedule: [SCHEDULE]
- Late payment interest: 8% per annum above Bank of England base rate (Late Payment of Commercial Debts (Interest) Act 1998)

clauses.title: PERFORMANCE STANDARDS
clauses.content:
3. PERFORMANCE STANDARDS
The Provider shall perform all services with reasonable care and skill in accordance with good industry practice and any applicable British Standards.

clauses.title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY
clauses.content:
4. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY
All intellectual property rights in work product created by the Provider shall vest in [CLIENT/PROVIDER] upon full payment, subject to the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988.

clauses.title: LIMITATION OF LIABILITY
clauses.content:
5. LIMITATION OF LIABILITY
The Provider's total liability under this Agreement shall not exceed the total fees paid or payable hereunder. Nothing in this Agreement excludes liability for death or personal injury caused by negligence or fraudulent misrepresentation.

clauses.title: INDEMNIFICATION
clauses.content:
6. INDEMNIFICATION
Each party agrees to indemnify the other against claims arising from breach of this Agreement or negligent acts, subject to the provisions of the Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977.

clauses.title: TERMINATION
clauses.content:
7. TERMINATION
Either party may terminate this Agreement by giving [NOTICE PERIOD] written notice. The Client may terminate immediately for material breach that remains unremedied after 14 days' written notice.

clauses.title: DISPUTE RESOLUTION
clauses.content:
8. DISPUTE RESOLUTION
Any disputes shall be resolved through mediation and, if unsuccessful, by the courts of England and Wales.

clauses.title: FORCE MAJEURE
clauses.content:
9. FORCE MAJEURE
Neither party shall be liable for delays caused by circumstances beyond their reasonable control, including acts of God, government action, or industrial disputes.

clauses.title: ENTIRE AGREEMENT
clauses.content:
10. ENTIRE AGREEMENT
This Agreement constitutes the entire agreement between the parties and supersedes all prior negotiations, representations, and agreements.

clauses.title: GOVERNING LAW
clauses.content:
11. GOVERNING LAW
This Agreement shall be governed by English law and subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the English courts.

clauses.title: DOCUMENT HEADER: CONFIDENTIALITY AGREEMENT (UK)
clauses.content:
CONFIDENTIALITY AGREEMENT (UK)

This Confidentiality Agreement is entered into between [DISCLOSING PARTY] ("Disclosing Party") and [RECEIVING PARTY] ("Receiving Party").

clauses.title: DEFINITION OF CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION
clauses.content:
1. DEFINITION OF CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION
"Confidential Information" means any and all non-public, confidential or proprietary information disclosed by the Disclosing Party, including but not limited to:
- Technical data, trade secrets, know-how
- Business plans, financial information
- Customer lists, supplier information
- Marketing strategies and plans
- Software, algorithms, and source code
- Personal data as defined by UK GDPR and Data Protection Act 2018

clauses.title: OBLIGATIONS OF RECEIVING PARTY
clauses.content:
2. OBLIGATIONS OF RECEIVING PARTY
The Receiving Party agrees to:
- Hold all Confidential Information in strict confidence
- Not disclose Confidential Information to third parties without written consent
- Use Confidential Information solely for the agreed evaluation purposes
- Take reasonable security measures to protect confidentiality
- Comply with UK GDPR and Data Protection Act 2018 regarding personal data

clauses.title: EXCEPTIONS
clauses.content:
3. EXCEPTIONS
This Agreement does not apply to information that:
- Is publicly available through no breach of this Agreement
- Was lawfully known to the Receiving Party prior to disclosure
- Is independently developed without use of Confidential Information
- Is required to be disclosed by law, court order, or regulatory authority

clauses.title: RETURN OF MATERIALS
clauses.content:
4. RETURN OF MATERIALS
Upon written request, the Receiving Party shall promptly return or securely destroy all materials containing Confidential Information and provide written certification of such destruction.

clauses.title: TERM
clauses.content:
5. TERM
This Agreement shall remain in effect for [TIME PERIOD] years from the date of execution, or indefinitely for trade secrets that qualify for protection under the Trade Secrets (Enforcement, etc.) Regulations 2018.

clauses.title: REMEDIES
clauses.content:
6. REMEDIES
The Receiving Party acknowledges that breach may cause irreparable harm for which damages would be an inadequate remedy, and the Disclosing Party shall be entitled to seek injunctive relief and other equitable remedies.

clauses.title: DATA PROTECTION
clauses.content:
7. DATA PROTECTION
Both parties acknowledge their obligations under UK GDPR and the Data Protection Act 2018. Where personal data is disclosed, the parties shall enter into appropriate data processing agreements.

clauses.title: GOVERNING LAW
clauses.content:
8. GOVERNING LAW
This Agreement shall be governed by English law and subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the English courts.

clauses.title: DOCUMENT HEADER: TERMINATION CLAUSES LIBRARY
clauses.content: TERMINATION CLAUSES LIBRARY

clauses.title: TERMINATION FOR CONVENIENCE
clauses.content:
1. TERMINATION FOR CONVENIENCE
"Either party may terminate this Agreement at any time, with or without cause, by providing [30/60/90] days written notice to the other party."

clauses.title: TERMINATION FOR CAUSE
clauses.content:
2. TERMINATION FOR CAUSE
"Either party may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice if the other party: (a) materially breaches this Agreement and fails to cure such breach within [30] days after written notice; (b) becomes insolvent or files for bankruptcy; or (c) ceases to conduct business in the ordinary course."

clauses.title: TERMINATION FOR NON-PAYMENT
clauses.content:
3. TERMINATION FOR NON-PAYMENT
"Company may terminate this Agreement immediately if Client fails to make any payment when due and such failure continues for [15] days after written notice."

clauses.title: TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT - AT WILL
clauses.content:
4. TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT - AT WILL
"Employment is at-will and may be terminated by either party at any time, with or without cause or notice, except as otherwise provided by law."

clauses.title: TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT - FOR CAUSE
clauses.content:
5. TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT - FOR CAUSE
"Company may terminate Employee's employment immediately for cause, including but not limited to: (a) willful misconduct; (b) breach of fiduciary duty; (c) conviction of a felony; (d) violation of company policies; or (e) failure to perform duties after written warning."

clauses.title: TERMINATION - SURVIVAL OF PROVISIONS
clauses.content:
6. TERMINATION - SURVIVAL OF PROVISIONS
"The following provisions shall survive termination of this Agreement: confidentiality, intellectual property, limitation of liability, and dispute resolution."

clauses.title: TERMINATION - EFFECT ON PAYMENT
clauses.content:
7. TERMINATION - EFFECT ON PAYMENT
"Upon termination, all unpaid amounts shall become immediately due and payable, except for amounts disputed in good faith."

clauses.title: TERMINATION - RETURN OF PROPERTY
clauses.content:
8. TERMINATION - RETURN OF PROPERTY
"Upon termination, each party shall promptly return all confidential information and property belonging to the other party."

clauses.title: TERMINATION - NON-SOLICITATION SURVIVAL
clauses.content:
9. TERMINATION - NON-SOLICITATION SURVIVAL
"The non-solicitation provisions contained herein shall survive termination for a period of [12/24] months."

clauses.title: TERMINATION - WIND-DOWN PERIOD
clauses.content:
10. TERMINATION - WIND-DOWN PERIOD
"Upon notice of termination, the parties shall cooperate in good faith to ensure an orderly wind-down of services over a period not to exceed [30] days."

clauses.title: DOCUMENT HEADER: LIABILITY AND INDEMNIFICATION CLAUSES LIBRARY
clauses.content: LIABILITY AND INDEMNIFICATION CLAUSES LIBRARY

clauses.title: LIMITATION OF LIABILITY - GENERAL
clauses.content:
1. LIMITATION OF LIABILITY - GENERAL
"IN NO EVENT SHALL EITHER PARTY BE LIABLE FOR ANY INDIRECT, INCIDENTAL, SPECIAL, CONSEQUENTIAL, OR PUNITIVE DAMAGES, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO LOSS OF PROFITS, DATA, OR USE, REGARDLESS OF THE THEORY OF LIABILITY."

clauses.title: LIMITATION OF LIABILITY - CAP
clauses.content:
2. LIMITATION OF LIABILITY - CAP
"EACH PARTY'S TOTAL LIABILITY ARISING OUT OF OR RELATED TO THIS AGREEMENT SHALL NOT EXCEED THE TOTAL AMOUNT PAID OR PAYABLE UNDER THIS AGREEMENT IN THE TWELVE (12) MONTHS PRECEDING THE EVENT GIVING RISE TO LIABILITY."

clauses.title: MUTUAL INDEMNIFICATION
clauses.content:
3. MUTUAL INDEMNIFICATION
"Each party shall indemnify, defend, and hold harmless the other party from and against any claims, damages, losses, and expenses arising from: (a) breach of this Agreement; (b) negligent acts or omissions; or (c) violation of applicable laws."

clauses.title: THIRD-PARTY INDEMNIFICATION
clauses.content:
4. THIRD-PARTY INDEMNIFICATION
"Provider shall indemnify and hold harmless Client from any third-party claims alleging that the services infringe any patent, copyright, or trademark, provided Client promptly notifies Provider of such claim."

clauses.title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY INDEMNIFICATION
clauses.content:
5. INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY INDEMNIFICATION
"Provider warrants that the services do not infringe any third-party intellectual property rights and shall defend and indemnify Client against any such claims."

clauses.title: DATA BREACH INDEMNIFICATION
clauses.content:
6. DATA BREACH INDEMNIFICATION
"Provider shall indemnify Client for any losses resulting from Provider's breach of data security obligations, including notification costs, credit monitoring, and regulatory fines."

clauses.title: EMPLOYEE INDEMNIFICATION
clauses.content:
7. EMPLOYEE INDEMNIFICATION
"Company shall indemnify Employee for actions taken in good faith within the scope of employment, except for willful misconduct or criminal acts."

clauses.title: DIRECTOR AND OFFICER INDEMNIFICATION
clauses.content:
8. DIRECTOR AND OFFICER INDEMNIFICATION
"Corporation shall indemnify directors and officers to the fullest extent permitted by law for actions taken in their official capacity."

clauses.title: EXCLUSIONS FROM INDEMNIFICATION
clauses.content:
9. EXCLUSIONS FROM INDEMNIFICATION
"Indemnification obligations shall not apply to claims arising from: (a) willful misconduct; (b) criminal acts; (c) breach of confidentiality; or (d) violation of law."

clauses.title: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS
clauses.content:
10. INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS
"Each party shall maintain comprehensive general liability insurance with minimum coverage of $[AMOUNT] and shall name the other party as an additional insured."

clauses.title: DOCUMENT HEADER: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY CLAUSES LIBRARY
clauses.content: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY CLAUSES LIBRARY

clauses.title: WORK FOR HIRE - GENERAL
clauses.content:
1. WORK FOR HIRE - GENERAL
"All work product, inventions, and intellectual property created by Contractor in connection with this Agreement shall be deemed work made for hire and shall be owned exclusively by Client."

clauses.title: ASSIGNMENT OF INVENTIONS - EMPLOYEE
clauses.content:
2. ASSIGNMENT OF INVENTIONS - EMPLOYEE
"Employee hereby assigns to Company all right, title, and interest in any inventions, discoveries, or improvements made during employment that relate to Company's business or use Company resources."

clauses.title: RETAINED RIGHTS
clauses.content:
3. RETAINED RIGHTS
"Each party retains all right, title, and interest in its pre-existing intellectual property. Nothing in this Agreement grants any license or ownership rights in such pre-existing IP."

clauses.title: LICENSE GRANT - LIMITED
clauses.content:
4. LICENSE GRANT - LIMITED
"Provider grants Client a non-exclusive, non-transferable license to use the deliverables solely for Client's internal business purposes during the term of this Agreement."

clauses.title: LICENSE GRANT - PERPETUAL
clauses.content:
5. LICENSE GRANT - PERPETUAL
"Upon full payment, Provider grants Client a perpetual, irrevocable, worldwide license to use, modify, and distribute the work product for any purpose."

clauses.title: JOINT OWNERSHIP
clauses.content:
6. JOINT OWNERSHIP
"Any intellectual property jointly developed by the parties shall be jointly owned, with each party having the right to use and license such IP without accounting to the other party."

clauses.title: MORAL RIGHTS WAIVER
clauses.content:
7. MORAL RIGHTS WAIVER
"To the extent permitted by law, Creator waives all moral rights in the work product, including rights of attribution and integrity."

clauses.title: PATENT WARRANTY
clauses.content:
8. PATENT WARRANTY
"Provider warrants that the deliverables do not infringe any valid patent and shall defend Client against any patent infringement claims."

clauses.title: COPYRIGHT NOTICE
clauses.content:
9. COPYRIGHT NOTICE
"All work product shall include the following copyright notice: '© [YEAR] [OWNER NAME]. All rights reserved.'"

clauses.title: TRADE SECRET PROTECTION
clauses.content:
10. TRADE SECRET PROTECTION
"The parties acknowledge that certain information may constitute trade secrets and agree to maintain such information in confidence and not use it except as authorized."

clauses.title: TRADEMARK LICENSE
clauses.content:
11. TRADEMARK LICENSE
"Client grants Provider a limited license to use Client's trademarks solely for the purpose of performing services under this Agreement."

clauses.title: OPEN SOURCE COMPLIANCE
clauses.content:
12. OPEN SOURCE COMPLIANCE
"Provider warrants that no open source software is included in the deliverables without Client's prior written consent and compliance with applicable licenses."

clauses.title: DOCUMENT HEADER: UK EMPLOYMENT LAW PRECEDENTS AND PRINCIPLES
clauses.content: UK EMPLOYMENT LAW PRECEDENTS AND PRINCIPLES

clauses.title: UNFAIR DISMISSAL PROTECTION
clauses.content:
1. UNFAIR DISMISSAL PROTECTION
Under Employment Rights Act 1996, employees with 2+ years' service are protected from unfair dismissal. Dismissal must be for a fair reason and follow a fair procedure.

Key Case: British Home Stores Ltd v. Burchell [1980] ICR 303 - Established the test for dismissal for misconduct: genuine belief based on reasonable investigation.

clauses.title: CONSTRUCTIVE DISMISSAL
clauses.content:
2. CONSTRUCTIVE DISMISSAL
"Constructive dismissal occurs when an employer's conduct makes continued employment impossible, entitling the employee to resign and claim unfair dismissal."

Key Case: Western Excavating (ECC) Ltd v. Sharp [1978] ICR 221 - Established that employer must breach a fundamental term of the contract.

clauses.title: DISCRIMINATION PROTECTIONS
clauses.content:
3. DISCRIMINATION PROTECTIONS
Equality Act 2010 protects against discrimination based on:
- Age, disability, gender reassignment, marriage/civil partnership
- Pregnancy/maternity, race, religion/belief, sex, sexual orientation

Key Case: Shamoon v. Chief Constable of the Royal Ulster Constabulary [2003] UKHL 11 - Established comparative approach to direct discrimination.

clauses.title: REASONABLE ADJUSTMENTS - DISABILITY
clauses.content:
4. REASONABLE ADJUSTMENTS - DISABILITY
Employers have a duty to make reasonable adjustments for disabled employees under Equality Act 2010.

Examples of Reasonable Adjustments:
- Flexible working arrangements
- Accessible premises modifications
- Providing assistive equipment
- Reallocating duties

Key Case: Archibald v. Fife Council [2004] UKHL 32 - Duty may require transferring disabled employee to higher grade position.

clauses.title: WORKING TIME REGULATIONS
clauses.content:
5. WORKING TIME REGULATIONS
Working Time Regulations 1998 implement EU Working Time Directive:
- Maximum 48-hour working week (can opt out)
- Minimum 20 days' paid annual leave plus bank holidays
- Rest breaks and daily/weekly rest periods

Key Case: Barber v. RJB Mining (UK) Ltd [1999] ICR 679 - Employees cannot be required to work more than 48 hours without opt-out.

clauses.title: WHISTLEBLOWING PROTECTION
clauses.content:
6. WHISTLEBLOWING PROTECTION
Public Interest Disclosure Act 1998 protects workers who make protected disclosures about wrongdoing.

Protected Disclosures:
- Criminal offences
- Health and safety dangers
- Environmental damage
- Miscarriages of justice

Key Case: Chesterton Global Ltd v. Nurmohamed [2017] EWCA Civ 979 - Clarified "public interest" test for protected disclosures.

clauses.title: RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS
clauses.content:
7. RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS
Post-employment restraints must protect legitimate business interests and be reasonable in scope and duration.

Key Case: Faccenda Chicken Ltd v. Fowler [1987] Ch 117 - Established categories of confidential information and enforceability of restraints.

clauses.title: TUPE TRANSFERS
clauses.content:
8. TUPE TRANSFERS
Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 protect employees when businesses transfer.

Key Case: Spijkers v. Gebroeders Benedik Abattoir CV [1986] ECR 1119 - Established multi-factor test for identifying relevant transfers.

clauses.title: COLLECTIVE REDUNDANCIES
clauses.content:
9. COLLECTIVE REDUNDANCIES
Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992 requires consultation when making 20+ redundancies within 90 days.

Key Case: UK Coal Mining Ltd v. NUM [2008] ICR 163 - Established that consultation must begin "in good time" before dismissals.

clauses.title: EQUAL PAY
clauses.content:
10. EQUAL PAY
Equality Act 2010 provides right to equal pay for equal work, work rated as equivalent, or work of equal value.

Key Case: Hayward v. Cammell Laird Shipbuilders Ltd [1988] AC 894 - Established term-by-term comparison approach to equal pay claims.

clauses.title: DOCUMENT HEADER: UK CONTRACT LAW PRECEDENTS AND PRINCIPLES
clauses.content: UK CONTRACT LAW PRECEDENTS AND PRINCIPLES

clauses.title: FORMATION OF CONTRACTS
clauses.content:
1. FORMATION OF CONTRACTS
Essential Elements:
- Offer: Clear, definite proposal
- Acceptance: Unqualified agreement to terms
- Consideration: Exchange of value or promise
- Intention to create legal relations
- Certainty of terms

Key Case: Carlill v. Carbolic Smoke Ball Co [1893] 1 QB 256 - Established principles of unilateral contracts and consideration.

clauses.title: OFFER AND ACCEPTANCE
clauses.content:
2. OFFER AND ACCEPTANCE
Offer must be distinguished from invitation to treat. Acceptance must be communicated and match the terms of the offer.

Key Cases:
- Fisher v. Bell [1961] 1 QB 394 - Goods in shop window are invitation to treat, not offer
- Entores Ltd v. Miles Far East Corporation [1955] 2 QB 327 - Postal rule does not apply to instantaneous communications

clauses.title: CONSIDERATION
clauses.content:
3. CONSIDERATION
"Consideration must be sufficient but need not be adequate." Past consideration is generally not valid consideration.

Key Cases:
- Chappell & Co Ltd v. Nestlé Co Ltd [1960] AC 87 - Chocolate bar wrappers constituted valid consideration
- Williams v. Roffey Bros [1991] 1 QB 1 - Practical benefit can constitute consideration

clauses.title: BREACH OF CONTRACT REMEDIES
clauses.content:
4. BREACH OF CONTRACT REMEDIES
Expectation Damages: Put claimant in position they would have been in if contract performed
Reliance Damages: Reimburse expenses incurred in reliance on contract
Restitution: Prevent unjust enrichment

Key Case: Hadley v. Baxendale (1854) 9 Exch 341 - Established remoteness test for consequential damages (still good law).

clauses.title: FRUSTRATION OF CONTRACT
clauses.content:
5. FRUSTRATION OF CONTRACT
Performance excused when supervening event makes performance impossible, illegal, or radically different.

Key Cases:
- Taylor v. Caldwell (1863) 3 B&S 826 - Contract frustrated when music hall burned down
- Davis Contractors Ltd v. Fareham UDC [1956] AC 696 - Established modern frustration doctrine

clauses.title: UNFAIR CONTRACT TERMS
clauses.content:
6. UNFAIR CONTRACT TERMS
Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977 and Consumer Rights Act 2015 regulate exclusion clauses and unfair terms.

Key Cases:
- Photo Production Ltd v. Securicor Transport Ltd [1980] AC 827 - Fundamental breach doctrine rejected
- Director General of Fair Trading v. First National Bank [2001] UKHL 52 - Test for unfair terms in consumer contracts

clauses.title: THIRD-PARTY RIGHTS
clauses.content:
7. THIRD-PARTY RIGHTS
Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act 1999 allows third parties to enforce contracts in certain circumstances.

Key Case: Beswick v. Beswick [1968] AC 58 - Established privity doctrine and its limitations (pre-1999 Act).

clauses.title: MISREPRESENTATION
clauses.content:
8. MISREPRESENTATION
False statements of fact that induce contract formation may give rise to remedies.

Key Cases:
- Hedley Byrne & Co Ltd v. Heller & Partners Ltd [1964] AC 465 - Established negligent misrepresentation
- Royscot Trust Ltd v. Rogerson [1991] 2 QB 297 - Damages under s.2(1) Misrepresentation Act 1967

clauses.title: DURESS AND UNDUE INFLUENCE
clauses.content:
9. DURESS AND UNDUE INFLUENCE
Contracts may be voidable if entered into under duress or undue influence.

Key Cases:
- Universe Tankships Inc v. International Transport Workers Federation [1983] 1 AC 366 - Economic duress
- Royal Bank of Scotland v. Etridge (No 2) [2001] UKHL 44 - Undue influence in surety cases

clauses.title: PENALTY CLAUSES
clauses.content:
10. PENALTY CLAUSES
Contractual provisions for breach are unenforceable if they constitute penalties rather than genuine pre-estimates of loss.

Key Case: Makdessi v. Cavendish Square Holdings [2015] UKSC 67 - Modern approach to penalty clauses, focusing on whether clause is extravagant or unconscionable.
